families.name: Maia (Portugal)
history: This is one of the five families described by ancient lineage books when Portugal kingdom was made.
This family has its history linked with the Monastery of Santo Tirso.

people.name: Aboazar Lovesendes
history: According to Mattoso, Aboazar Lovesendes' birth is described in the legend of Gaia (Mattoso, José, 1987, pp. 208; Mattoso, José, 1969, pp. 492). His existence can be confirmed through two documents (Mattoso, José, 1987, pp. 208; Mattoso, José, 1969, pp. 492, 493), one of which was transcribed by Antonio C. de Sousa (Sousa, Antonio C. de, 1739, pp. 540; Correia, Francisco C, 2008, pp. 97).

His children were suggested for António C. de Sousa (Mattoso, José, 1987, pp. 208,209; Sousa, Antonio C. de, 1739, pp. 540; Correia, Francisco C, 2008, pp. 97), for this reason, we prefer to thread them as hypothesis, ignoring the fact that they signed a distinct patronymic.

The "Livro Velho de Linhagens" suggests only the sons Trastamiro Alboazar and Hermigio (Herculano, Alexandre, 1860, Scriptores, Volumen I, Fascicvlvs II, pp. 181). This suggestion was accepted by count Don Pedro (Sousa, Manuel de F., et al., 1646, Dom Pedro, pp. 116-117) and Gaio (Felgueiras, Gaio, 1939, Tomo 18, pp. 11).

marriages.name: Unisco Godinhes
history: Marriage cited in a copied document for António C. de Sousa (Sousa, Antonio C. de, 1739, pp. 540; Mattoso, José, 1987, pp. 208).

children.name: Lovesendo
history: José Mattoso cites António C. de Sousa as a source (Mattoso, José, 1987, pp. 208; Mattoso, José, 1969, pp. 492-493).

children.name: Ermígio
history: José Mattoso cites António C. de Sousa as a source (Mattoso, José, 1987, pp. 208; Mattoso, José, 1969, pp. 492-493).

children.name: Trastemiro
history: José Mattoso cites António C. de Sousa as a source (Mattoso, José, 1987, pp. 208; Mattoso, José, 1969, pp. 492-493).

children.name: Ausenda
history: José Mattoso cites António C. de Sousa as a source (Mattoso, José, 1987, pp. 208; Mattoso, José, 1969, pp. 492-493).

people.name: Trastemiro Aboazar
history: Despite the citations by António C. de Sousa (Sousa, Antonio C. de, 1739, pp. 540) we only have nobiliarchies references about him (Mattoso, José, 1987, pp. 211; Mattoso, José, 1969, pp. 494).

When we talk about his wife, the nobiliarchies cannot converge: The "Livro Velho de Linhagens" marriages him with Dórdia Soares (Herculano, Alexandre, 1860, Scriptores, Volumen I, Fascicvlvs II, pp. 181), while Don Pedro informs that he marriage Dórdia Osores, and he had another marriage with Mendola Gonçalves (Sousa, Manuel. et al., 1646, Dom Pedro, pp. 117), this confusion conducted Juan B. Lavaña to add notes to Don Pedro's book, finally Felgueiras Gaio followed exactly what Don Pedro had proposed (Felgueiras, Gaio, 1939, Tomo 18, pp. 11).

marriages.name: Dordia Soares
history: José Mattoso cites only nobiliarchy as source for this marriage (Mattoso, José, 1987, pp. 211; Mattoso, José, 1969, pp. 494).

children.name: Gonçalo Trastemires
history: Their hypothetical grandsons were patrons of the Monastery of Santo Tirso (Mattoso, José, 1987, pp. 211; Mattoso, José, 1969, pp. 494).

people.name: Gonçalo Trastemires
history: He conquered Montemor from the Arabic people in 1034 A.D./Era 1072 (Mattoso, José, 1969, pp. 495; Herculano, Alexandre, 1860, Scriptores, Volvmen I, Fascicvlvs I, pp. 9). He confirmed a donation in Leça in 1035 A.D./Era 1073 (Mattoso, José, 1969, pp. 495; Herculano, Alexandre, 1860, Diplomata et Chartae, Volvumen I, pp. 135-137). Furthermore, he passed away during year 1038 A.D./Era 1076 (Mattoso, José, 1969, pp. 495; Herculano, Alexandre, 1860, Scriptores, Volvmen I, Fascicvlvs I, pp. 9).

The linage books made confusion creating an appearance that he had different marriages (Sousa, Manuel de F. e all, 1646, Dom Pedro, pp. 117, 455; Felgueiras, Gaio, 1939, Tomo 18, pp. 11; Herculano, Alexandre, 1860, Scriptores, Volumen I, Fascicvlvs II, pp. 153, 181), but we should understand these marriages as either copy errors, or woman that he did not marriage (Mattoso, José, 1969, pp. 495), so we follow José Mattoso accepting Unisco Sisnandes, daughter of Sesnão Dias, as his unique wife (Mattoso, José, 1969, pp. 495; Herculano, Alexandre, 1860, Scriptores, Volumen I, Fascicvlvs II, pp. 181). We are accepting this, because there was an Unisco Sisnandes cited in a document as the grandmother of Soeiro Mendes (Herculano, Alexandre, 1860, Diplomata et Chartae, Volvumen I, Fascicvlvs IV, pp. 518).

marriages.name: Unisco Sisnandes
history: According to the "Livro Velho" (Herculano, Alexandre, 1860, Scriptores, Volumen I, Fascicvlvs II, pp. 181), but successive copies modified her patronymic, and she was renamed to Unisco Fernandes (Mattoso, José, 1969, pp. 495; Herculano, Alexandre, 1860, Scriptores, Volumen I, Fascicvlvs II, pp. 181). A possible confirmation for this marriage can be found in a document where his grandson Soeiro Mendes names her as Unisco Sisnandes (Herculano, Alexandre, 1860, Diplomata et Chartae, Volvumen I, Fascicvlvs IV, pp. 518), but the document does not give information about her relationship with Gonçalo Trastamires.

Don Pedro cites her as "Usco Soares" daughter of Sesnão Dias (Sousa, Manuel de F. e all, 1646, Dom Pedro, pp. 117, 455), but when a person used the patronymic Soares during those days, this means that she was the daughter of a Soeiro instead of a Sesnão. Gaio modified once again the history writing that: "Usco Soares" was the daughter of Simão Dias (Felgueiras, Gaio, 1939, Tomo 18, pp. 11).

marriages.name: Unisco Sisnandes
history:
It is common to read in genealogical websites that allow users to make their own family tree a hypothetical link between her and Sisnando Davidiz (Gutierrez, Andrés G., Real Academia de La Historia), but is this hypothesis correct? Let us use the scientific method (History Tracers (2024): Scientific Method) to answer the question:
  • The scientific method starts with the hypotheses:
    • HYPOTHESIS 1: Unisco Sisnandes is a Sisnando Davidiz's daughter, because she has the patronymic Sisnandes.
    • HYPOTHESIS 2: Unisco Sisnandes is not Sisnando Davidiz's daughter.
  • After having the hypotheses, it is necessary to look for primary sources that allow to confirm them:
    • HYPOTHESIS 1: there is not any documentation linking her to Sisnando Davidiz..
    • HYPOTHESIS 2: Inside the lineage books, her supposed fathers have the patronymic Dias (Mattoso, José, 1969, pp.495). Her last citation in a document happens together with her [son] Mendo Gonçalves in 1045 A.D./Era 1083 (Mattoso, José, 1969, pp.495; Herculano, Alexandre, 1860, Diplomata et Chartae, Volvumen I, Fascicvlvs II, pp. 209-211.)
  • The THEORY is made using primary sources and comparing them with the hypotheses:
    • A HYPOTHESIS 1 does not have a solid basis, because the unique connection with her father is the patronymic, and this is not conclusive during the 11th century, mainly when we have more than one Sisnando documented (Abranches de Soveral, Manuel, 2003). Now about the HYPHOTESIS 2, it is observed that lineage books do not give the patronymic "Davidiz" to her supposed father. There are still chronological issues (anachronism): while the Sisnando Davidiz citations happen between 1064 A.D./Era 1102 and 1091 A.D./Era 1129 (Gutierrez, Andrés G., Real Academia de La Historia), her last citation with her son was decades before. Considering that her [son] was already an adult in the year 1045 A.D./Era 1083, we have to accept that Unisco Sisnandes was born around the year 1000 A.D./Era 1038, so when the first citation to Sisnando Davidiz appears in documentation around the year 1060 A.D./Era 1098 (Aillet, C., 2011, pp. 87), he would be more or less 90 years old. Before to select between the hypotheses, it is necessary to bring that the documented Sisnando Davidiz's daughter, that had a marriage to Ribadouro's family, is named Elvira Sisnandes, and her husband, Martim Moniz, is documented only in last years of 11th century and beginning of 12th century (Abranches de Soveral, Manuel, 2003 ; Merendeiro, Cristina João B., 2021, pp. 21, 23, footnotes). These facts allow us to accept the HYPOTHESIS 2. Q.E.D. (Util new documents appear that can change current understanding, because science always advances with data.)

marriages.name: Mécia Godins
history: According to "Livro Velho de Linhagens" (Herculano, Alexandre, 1860, Scriptores, Volumen I, Fascicvlvs II, pp. 153).

marriages.name: Mécia Rodrigues
history: According to nobiliarchies (Felgueiras, Gaio, 1939, Tomo 18, pp. 11; Sousa, Manuel de F., et al., 1646, Dom Pedro, pp. 117).

children.name: Mendo Gonçalves
history: We treat this as a theory, because there is documentation that allows to think about this possibility (Herculano, Alexandre, 1860, Diplomata et Chartae, Volvumen I, Fascicvlvs IV, pp. 518), but the cited documentation does not prove the relationship.

children.name: Gontinha Gonçalves
history: According to José Mattoso (Mattoso, José, 1987, pp. 212; Mattoso, José, 1969, pp. 495).

children.name: Aragunta Gonçalves
history: Hypothesis of A. A. Fernandes (Mattoso, José, 1987, pp. 212).

people.name: Mendo Gonçalves
history: José Mattoso identifies "menendo guntsalbez" as a person ahead of a judgment in Braga in year 1053 A.D./Era 1091 (Mattoso, José, 1969, pp. 495; Herculano, Alexandre, 1860, Diplomata et Chartae, Volvumen I, Fascicvlvs II, pp. 236-237) and he also suggests that he could be the same person that confirmed a document with his [mother] during the year of 1045 A.D./Era 1083 (Mattoso, José, 1969, pp. 495; Herculano, Alexandre, 1860, Diplomata et Chartae, Volvumen I, Fascicvlvs II, pp. 209-211), finally he also identifies him as one of "infanções de Portugal" (Mattoso, José, 1969, pp. 495; Diplomata et Chartae, Volvumen I, Fascicvlvs II, pp. 263).
Mendo Gonçalves passed away during the year of 1065 A.D../Era 1103 (Mattoso, José, 1969, pp. 495; Herculano, Alexandre, 1860, Scriptores, Volvmen I, Fascicvlvs I, pp. 9).

marriages.name: Ledegúndia Soares, Tainha
history: We treat this marriage as a hypothesis, because it appears only in lineage books, these books also add that she was the daughter of Suer Guedas da Varzea (Mattoso, José, 1969, pp. 495-496; Herculano, Alexandre, 1860, Scriptores, Volumen I, Fascicvlvs II, pp. 153).

children.name: Gonçalo Mendes, o Lidador
history: The Count Don Pedro describes many details about his life (Sousa, Manuel de F., . et al., 1646, Dom Pedro, pp. 120-123), and he also attributed to him generation through a marriage that never happened (Mattoso, José, 1969, pp. 496).
The relationship with his father appears in a document (Mattoso, José, 1969, pp. 496; Herculano, Alexandre, 1860, Diplomata et Chartae, Volvumen I, Fascicvlvs III, pp. 320).

children.name: Soeiro Mendes, o Bom
history: The relationship with his parents is confirmed through documents where he appears with his brother "gundisalvo menendiz"/"gundisalvo mdiz" (Mattoso, José, 1969, pp. 496; Liber Fidei, Arquiivo Distrital Braga, img 49).

people.name: Aragunta Gonçalves
history: According to A. A. Fernandes (Mattoso, José, 1987, pp. 212).

people.name: Gontinha Gonçalves
history: According to José Mattoso (Mattoso, José, 1987, pp. 212; Mattoso, José, 1969, pp. 495).
